page.pageNote: Articles supporting Andrew Curtin for governor.
List of proprietors same as on March 21, 1860, p. 4.

div.head: Cincinnati Platform
div.excerpt: The Cincinnati platform is a delusion and a cheat.
div.summary: Editorial condemns the Democratic Party's 1856 platform at the Cincinnati convention, as protective of slavery.

div.head: Hot and Cold
div.excerpt: We would like to know which is genuine democracy; the Free Trade dogma of the Cincinnati resolve, or the protection sentiment of the Reading Convention. We would like to know whether the faithful, in this part of the State, endorse Foster's antiLecomptonism--by accepting him as their candidate, without his recantation--or if they intend to stab him in the dark, as the Buchananites did Douglas in Illinois.
div.summary: Editorial suggests the state Democrats and the Valley Spirit are two-faced in supporting a national party committed to free trade while advocating protectionism in their home state.

div.head: Information Desired
div.summary: Editorial seeks more information about a reputed brawl in the executive session of the U.S. Senate between two Democratic Senators.

div.head: The Homestead Bill
div.excerpt: Mr. Wigfall's threat to propose a distribution of money and slaves to each freeman sufficiently indicates the spirit in which the Slave Power has determined to fight the Homestead bill.
div.summary: Editorial on the homestead bill before U.S. Senate.

div.head: Spring Elections.
div.summary: List of elected officials by township and office.

div.head: Foundry and Machine Shop
div.summary: Notice of the extensive facilities at Frick's foundry and machine shop.

div.head: A Valuable Book.
div.summary: Notice of book seller canvassing the county for subscriptions for "History of Slavery and the Slave Trade" which editors highly recommend.

div.head: Improve Your Penmanship
div.summary: Notice of classes taught by Mrs. Crocker for writing and penmanship.

div.head: Removal
div.summary: G. W. Brewer moved his law office to West Market street in the Arcade building, fourth door from the hotel corner.

page.pageNote: Proceedings of the first Republican Convention ever held in Missouri.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Mr. William Wilson Elliot married Miss Mary Ann Typer, daughter of Mrs. Margaret Typer, on March 21.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Mr. Issac Miller married Miss Margaret Catharine Stevick on March 22.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Mr. William Elder married Mrs. Lydia Kinser on March 22 at the Union Hotel in Philadephia.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Elizabeth Wolff, age 39 years 1 month and 21 days, died in Amberson's Valley on March 14.

div.head: A List of Grand and Traverse Jurors
div.summary: List of Jurors, see March 21, 1860, p. 5.
